TD.P: Golden and Silver Rules
Golden Rule
Card text supersedes rules text. Whenever a card fundamentally contradicts the rules, the card's indication is what is true.
Silver Rule
Card text uses different terminology than rules. Card text should be interpreted according to these rules, not as though it were text within these rules.

Card, when written in card effects, is shorthand for "Main Deck card." Runes, legends, and battlefields are not considered cards when executing the abilities and effects of game objects. They are considered cards for the purposes of these rules.
Cards refer to themselves in the first person.
“Can’t beats Can”

TD.H3: Cards that forbid actions or effects, as a broad method of determination, supersede cards that allow or permit that same action or effect.

TD.P: When executing card text, do as much as you can, ignoring impossible instructions.

TD.H3: If all of a card’s instructions are impossible, it is still played and resolved, but nothing happens.

TD.P: Game Concepts
Deck Construction
Riftbound is a Trading Card Game where a player must provide their own cards to play against other players.
To play Riftbound, a player must have two Decks, a Champion Legend, and a number of Battlefields determined by the Mode of Play.
This is placed in the Legend Zone at the start of the game.
This will dictate the Domain Identity of the Main Deck.
Cards included in your Deck must abide by your Domain Identity.
Your deck’s Domain Identity is dictated by the domains of your Champion Legend. In the default card frame, these domains appear as symbols in the legend’s upper left corner.
If a card has a single Domain, then that card is permitted in the Domain Identity that corresponds to the same Domain.
If a card has more than one Domain, then that card is permitted only in a Domain Identity that contains all of the indicated Domains on that card.
A Main Deck of at least 40 cards 1 Chosen Champion Unit Units Gear Spells
Chosen Champion
This will be placed in the Champion Zone at the start of the game.

Must be a champion unit with a champion tag that matches the tag on your Champion Legend. Example: Loose Cannon has the tag Jinx. Therefore, a player could choose Jinx, Rebel or Jinx, Demolitionist as their Chosen Champion, because they also have the tag Jinx. Example: Tibbers has the tag Annie, but it is a signature unit, not a champion unit. It cannot be your Chosen Champion, even if your Champion Legend has the tag Annie.

A player’s Chosen Champion is both the specific card chosen for this slot during Deck Building and also any Champion Unit with the same name as the specific card selected for this specific slot during the course of play. Example: A player chose Jinx, Rebel as their Chosen Champion. One copy of Jinx, Rebel starts the game in their Chosen Champion zone. Any additional copies of Jinx, Rebel in their Main Deck, their hand, their trash, or on the board also count as their Chosen Champion for any game rules and effects that care about Chosen Champion status during the game.
Your Main Deck can include up to 3 copies of the same named card.
This includes your Chosen Champion. Example: A deck could include Volibear, Furious as its Chosen Champion and still include 2 more copies of Volibear, Furious.
Cards have different names even if they represent the same character. Example: A deck could include 3 copies of Yasuo, Remorseful and 3 copies of Yasuo, Windrider, because they have different names.
Subject to Domain Identity.
Your deck may only contain 3 total Signature cards that have the same Champion tag as your Champion Legend.
Regardless of name, a deck may only contain a sum total of 3 Signature cards.
All of the Signature cards must have the Champion tag that corresponds to the Champion Legend of the deck.
Signature cards are not Champion units and cannot be placed in the Champion Zone.
During Gameplay, the Main Deck is Secret Information.
It cannot be looked through or revealed unless instructed by a card effect.
Rune Deck
12 Rune Cards
Cards in this deck must be of the Domain Identity of your Champion Legend.
Must be shuffled and kept separate from the Main Deck.
Battlefields
The number will be dictated by your Mode of Play.
Subject to Domain Identity if applicable.
Cannot include more than one of a Battlefield of the same name when there are more than one required for the deck.
Setup
Spaces
The Play Area includes a space for Game Objects referred to as The Board.
The Board is divided into several Zones.
The Base
One per player.
The space each player always has access to play their Units and Gear to.
Each Base is a Location.
Other players cannot have Game Objects they control in another player's Base.
The Base also houses each player's Runes that are on The Board.
The Battlefield Zone
Multiple Battlefields will be here, typically one per player, but occasionally less.
The space where Battlefields are located during gameplay.
Each Battlefield is individually a Location.
The Facedown Zones
Each Battlefield is associated with a sub-zone called a Facedown Zone, a single logical space that a card can be put facedown in through various Game Effects.
Each Facedown Zone has a maximum occupancy of one card.
Cards can only be placed in or occupy the Facedown Zone if the controller of the card also controls the associated Battlefield.
If the Hidden card's controller loses Control of the Battlefield, the card in the Facedown Zone is removed during the next Cleanup.
See rule 318. Cleanups for more information.
See rule 408. Hide for more information.
Facedown Zones are not locations.
The Legend Zone
The space for each player's Champion Legend.
This is not a location.
The Champion Legend here is a Game Object.
See rule 119. Game Objects for more information.
The Champion Legend cannot be removed, moved, or displaced from this zone.
The Play Area also includes Non-Board Zones.
The Trash
This space is where cards are placed when they are killed or discarded, when they finish being executed as spells, when they are moved to the trash as an effect, etc.
Represents cards that have been used or spent.
Each player has a separate trash.
A card owned by a player can never, for any reason, be put into a trash of another player. If it would be, it's put into its owner's trash instead.
The cards in the Trash are unordered. Their sequence does not matter, and they may be reorganized.
The cards in any player's Trash are Public Information.
See rule 127. Privacy for more information.
The Champion Zone
The space each player puts their Chosen Champion at the start of the game.
The Chosen Champion here cannot be returned to this zone by normal means.
If a Chosen Champion is instructed to be returned to this zone, it can only do so if there is not a card already in this zone.
The Chosen Champion can be played from here as normal, following the rules of Playing a Card.
See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
The Main Deck Zone
The space for the player's Main Deck.
Primarily houses the face-down deck during gameplay.
The order of cards in the deck is Secret Information during the course of play.
See rule 127. Privacy for more information.
The Rune Deck Zone
The space for the player's Rune Deck.
Primarily houses the face-down runes during gameplay.
The order of runes in the deck is Secret Information during the course of play.
See rule 127. Privacy for more information.
Banishment
This space is where cards are placed when they are banished by a spell or effect.
Represents cards that have been removed from play in a more difficult-to-recover way, or a temporary space to hold cards while effects are being processed.
Each player has a separate banishment.
A card owned by a player can never, for any reason, be put into the banishment of another player. If it would be, it's put into its owner's banishment instead.
The cards in the banishment are unordered. Their sequence does not matter, and they may be reorganized.
The cards in any player's Banishment are Public Information.
See rule 127. Privacy for more information.
Some spells or effects may reference cards placed into banishment directly.
Effects that reference cards in banishment only do so by means of also putting the cards there.
The effects or references to cards in banishment do not count as Choosing.
The effects or references to cards in banishment do not count as Attachment.
The Hand
Each player has a collection of cards they may Play cards from.
This is the location cards go when Drawn.
The cards in a player's hand are Private Information.
The number of cards in a player's hand is Public Information.
The hand can be targeted as a zone, and cards there can be affected by spells and effects when specified.
A card owned by a player can never, for any reason, be put into the hand of another player. If it would be, it's put into its owner's hand instead.
All Game Objects in the collective Play Areas are Public Information.
Any player may view, or be provided with the details of the face-up information printed on the cards in the Play Area.
The State of all Game Objects in the Play Area is also Public Information.
Examples:
If a Unit is Buffed
If a Gear is Exhausted
Etc.
Whenever a Game Object changes zones to or from a Non-Board Zone, all Temporary Modifications of all kinds cease to be tracked on it in all capacities.
Examples:
Damage is cleared.
Buffs are removed.
Temporarily granted Keywords are no longer granted.
Setup Process
Each player separates their Champion Legend and places it in the Legend Zone.
Each player separates their Chosen Champion and places it in the Champion Zone.
Each player sets aside their Battlefields.
Your Mode of Play will dictate how these are used and placed into the Battlefield Zone.
See rule 458. Modes of Play for more information.
Each player shuffles their decks, separately, then places them into their respective Zones.
The Main Deck is placed in the Main Deck Zone.
The Rune Deck is placed in the Rune Deck Zone.
Determine Turn Order using any fair random method agreed on by all players.
Turn Order is established as a repeating set of the players.
The Mode of Play will specify how to determine a First Player.
If not otherwise specified, Seating then determines the sequence, play proceeding clockwise from the First Player.
The First Player is the player who becomes the Turn Player first.
Turn Order repeats until the game ends.
See the selected Mode of Play for any adjustments to each player's first turn.
See rule 458. Modes of Play for more information.
Players each draw 4.
In turn order, players perform their Mulligan.
A player may choose up to two cards in their hand. They set those cards aside.
Then, that player draws as many cards as they set aside.
Finally, that player Recycles the cards that were set aside.
See rule 403. Recycle for more information.
Begin play with the First Player taking their turn.
Game Objects
A Game Object is any game piece that can produce one or more Game Effects or grant prerequisites for players to take Game Actions.
A Game Object does not include nor preclude any inherent properties beyond the ability to produce, or act as the prerequisite for, Game Effects and Game Actions.
A Game Object can be a literal object or a logical object.
Game Objects include, but are not limited to, the following:
Main Deck cards in any zone
Runes in any zone
Legends
Battlefields
Tokens
Abilities of any type on the chain
Buffs and other status markers
Cards
Riftbound games are composed of players playing the cards in their respective decks.
Ownership

For gameplay purposes, a card's Owner is the player who brought it into the game, either as their Champion Legend, one of their Battlefields, or part of their Main Deck or Rune Deck. The legal owner of a card doesn't matter during gameplay.
Example: Bo didn't bring a deck, so Alice loans him a deck. During the game, Bo is considered the owner of those cards, even though legally they belong to Alice.
Privacy
A card will always exist in one of the many Zones described during Setup.
A card will have a different level of Privacy based on where it resides at a given time
Secret: This level of Privacy indicates that neither player may read or look at the face of the card.
Private: This level of Privacy indicates that only the controller of a card on the board or the owner of a card in any other zone may read or look at the face of the card.
Example: Cards in a player's hand are owned by that player. Only that player may read or look at their faces.
Example: If a player controls a facedown card at a battlefield, that player and only that player may read or look at that card's face, regardless of who owns that card.
Public: This level of Privacy indicates that any player may read or look at the face of the card.
Back Side
The back side of a card is the side with the Riftbound logo.
There is a unique pattern of back side for each of the three categories of card: Main Deck cards, Rune Deck cards, and Battlefields and Champion Legends.
The back side of a card is presented to conceal information for Private and Secret information cards. For example, cards in the Main Deck and cards in hand have their back side presented.
The term facedown is used to describe the state during regular play of having a card's back side presented on the Board. A facedown card’s front side is considered Private Information.
Front Side
The front side of a card is the opposite of its back.
This is also referred to as a front face.
This can be identified in situations where the back is not easily discernible by the presence of the Play Cost in the upper left corner of the card.
Cards, when played, are played with their front face presented.
The term face up is used to describe the state during regular play of having a card's front face presented

Cards are considered to be Public Information while in this state, even if obscured by other cards in a pile. Example: The Trash is Public Information because all cards there have their front face presented even while stacked.
Cost
Main Deck cards have a Cost, listed in the upper left corner of the front face of the card.
See rule 161. Rune Pools for more information.
Energy Cost
The numeral listed in the Cost element in the upper left corner of the card.
Power cost
The symbols, listed vertically, in the Cost element in the upper left corner of the card.
This section may not be present on every card.
Effects that need to determine a card’s cost for any purpose always use its base cost, even if that cost is altered or ignored as the card is played.

Example: Sky Splitter is a spell that costs 8 Energy and says in part “This spell's Energy cost is reduced by the highest Might among units you control.” Lux, Illuminated is a unit that says “When you play a spell that costs 5 or more, give me +3 [M] this turn.” If a player who controls Lux plays Sky Splitter, Lux’s ability will trigger, regardless of how much was actually paid for Sky Splitter.
Name
Each card has a name that identifies it uniquely.
This is usually located in the middle of the card.
Cards that are printed in different languages but represent the same card are considered to have the same name for the purposes of deckbuilding and gameplay.
Example: Chemtech Enforcer in English and its counterpart in Chinese are considered the same card, despite the Name element on the card reading differently.

Some cards have both a short name and a subtitle. For all purposes, including rules and deckbuilding, such a card’s name is “[Short Name], [Subtitle]”. Example: Kai’Sa, Evolutionary and Kai’Sa, Survivor both have the short name Kai’Sa, but they have different names. You can include 3 of each in your deck under normal deckbuilding rules. If one of them is your Chosen Champion, the other is not.
Category
A card can have one or more Categories and Sub-Categories based on the properties of its front and back sides.
These Categories and Sub-Categories dictate the behaviors of the card during play.
Spells and other effects can refer to categories, sub-categories, supertypes, card types, tags, and other characteristics inclusively or exclusively.
Example: A "non-unit card" is any card that is not a unit.
Example: A "unit" is any game object that is a unit, regardless of any other categories it belongs to.
Main Deck Cards begin the game in the Main Deck or (in the case of a Chosen Champion) the Champion Zone.
Permanents
An umbrella sub-category encompassing Main Deck Game Objects that remain on the board after being played.
Unit and Gear are permanent types.
Spells
A sub-category encompassing Main Deck cards with the spell type, which do not remain on the board after being played.
Rune Deck Cards begin the game in the Rune Deck.
Runes

A sub-category encompassing cards with the rune type. These are channeled rather than played. They remain on the board after being channeled, but they are not permanents, as they are not Main Deck cards.
Non-Deck Cards are not part of any deck and begin the game in a zone determined by their type.
Battlefields
A sub-category encompassing cards with the battlefield type. They are not played or channeled. They start the game on the board.
Legends
A sub-category encompassing cards with the legend type. They are not played or channeled. They start the game in the Legend Zone and cannot leave it during play.
Supertypes are Categories that may apply to game objects of multiple types. They are listed before a card’s type.
Champion is a supertype that applies exclusively to units. It impacts the rules for deckbuilding.
See rule 103.2.a. Chosen Champion for more information.
Signature is a supertype that may apply to game objects of any card type. It impacts the rules for deckbuilding.
See rule 103.2.d. for more information about Signature cards.
Token is a supertype applied to temporary game objects of any card type.
See rule 173. Tokens for more information.
Tags are Categories that may apply to game objects of multiple types. They are listed after a card’s type.
Tags have no innate rules meaning, but may be referenced by game rules and card effects.
Tags used to link Legends, Champion Units, and Signature cards are known as Champion Tags.
Domain
Most cards belong to one or more of six Domains, identified by one or more symbols in the lower right corner.
Each Domain has an associated color, a unique symbol, and a shorthand used to represent that symbol in written text.
Fury is associated with the color red and represented by a circular symbol with three projecting points. Its shorthand is [R].
Calm is associated with the color green and represented by a symbol resembling a leaf. Its shorthand is [G].
Mind is associated with the color blue and represented by a symbol resembling a sun and moon. Its shorthand is [B].
Body is associated with the color orange and represented by a blocky diamond-shaped symbol. Its shorthand is [O].
Chaos is associated with the color purple and represented by a hexagonal symbol with swirls emanating from its center. Its shorthand is [P].
Order is associated with the color yellow and represented by an angular winged symbol. Its shorthand is [Y].
Rules Text
All cards have a section that describes how they affect the game. This section is known as the Rules Text of the card.
This section may contain:
Abilities
Abilities are discrete pieces of text that describe what a card may or must do.
See rule 357. Abilities for more information.
They may appear on any card.
Instructions
Instructions are a type of text that appears on spells and within abilities.
They describe the actions to be taken as the spell or ability resolves.
Keywords
Keywords are short words or phrases that represent longer abilities or instructions.
See rule 726. Keywords for more information.
Keywords may or may not have reminder text.
Reminder Text
Reminder text appears in italics and parentheses.
Its purpose is to summarize relevant rules, including keywords and other rules.
The presence, absence, or exact wording of reminder text has no effect on game function.
Symbols
Rules text sometimes contains symbols that express game concepts. Each symbol also has a shorthand used to represent it in written text.

The cost of Exhausting a Permanent is represented by the “exhaust symbol,” which resembles a card turning sideways. Its shorthand is [E]. (Some previous rules information has given its shorthand as [T].)
Might is represented by the “Might symbol,” which resembles a sword and shield. Its shorthand is [M]. (Some previous rules information has given its shorthand as [S].)
Power of a specific Domain is represented by its domain symbol and the corresponding shorthand.
See rule 133. Domain for more information.
Power of any Domain is represented by a swirling rainbow symbol. Its shorthand is [A].
When required as a cost, [A] can be paid by Power of any Domain.
When Added to a player’s Rune Pool, [A] can be spent to pay a Power cost of any Domain.
Power of a domain corresponding to a card’s own Domain is not represented by a symbol, but appears in these rules similarly to other symbols. Its shorthand is [C].
When a [C] shorthand is printed on a card as reminder text, it assumes that card’s usual Domain, but it still means “one Power of this card’s Domain.”
A [C] shorthand on a card with no Domain or with multiple Domains is processed as [A] instead.
Rules text can be blank.
A card’s Rules Text is Inactive while that card is Attached to another card.
See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
See rule 720 Inactive for more information.
The presence of text, rules, Keywords, and other effects can still be referenced and detected by other game effects, even while Rules Text is Inactive.
Effect Text
Some cards have a separate section of text below the Rules Text. This is referred to as the Effect Text.
Effect Text can contain additional Abilities.
Effect Text can be blank.
Effect Text is inactive unless the card with the Effect Text is Attached to another card.
See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
See rule 720 Inactive for more information.
The abilities in the Effect Text section of a card are appended to the Rules Text of the card to which the card with the Effect Text is Attached.
Might Bonus
Some cards have a Might Bonus in their lower right corner, expressed as an operator plus an integer.
A card’s Might Bonus can be +0.
A card’s Might Bonus modulates the Might of the card to which the card that has the Might Bonus is Attached.
See rule 716 Attachment for more information.
The Might Bonus is applied while Attached and stops applying as soon as the card with the Might Bonus is no longer Attached.
If the card to which a card with a Might Bonus is Attached has no Might value, the Might Bonus is ignored.
Flavor Text
Flavor text is text that appears at the bottom of some cards to provide aesthetic enjoyment. It conveys no gameplay information.
Example: The card Void Seeker features a quote from the character Kai'Sa. It does not have the Kai'Sa tag and has no gameplay connection to the Champion unit Kai'Sa.
Flavor text is located at the bottom of the section provided for rules text, usually in a shaded bar. It appears in italics.
Illustration
Each card has an illustration. It conveys no gameplay information.
Units
Unit is:
A Game Object
While on the Board:
Units are at one of several Locations while on the Board: a Battlefield or their Base.
Units and their details are Public Information while on the Board.
Units can be chosen, affected, or manipulated by spells, affects, or game actions that specify Units.
Units can be Killed.
See rule 415. Kill for more information.
While in the Trash:
Units are treated as Cards, similar to when in the Hand.
They retain the properties of being a Unit, but are not on the Board and thus cannot take actions or be affected by spells, abilities, or game actions that target Units on the Board.
Units can be affected by spells and game effects that target Units in the Trash.
A Card Type
This is a unique identifier that some spells or abilities will use to restrict what they can choose or affect.
The card type is relevant in all zones.
Damage is a marked value that is applied to Units.
Damage is not a Game Object.
Damage is a value tracked per-Unit.
Damage tracks how close a Unit is to being Killed.
See rule 415. Kill for more information.
Damage can be Healed.
See rule 405. Heal for more information.
Units have multiple Intrinsic Properties unique to them:
Tag: A Unit has zero or more Tags representing one or more champions, regions, factions, or species it belongs to.
These have no intrinsic rules or behaviors by themselves.
Spells, abilities, and game actions can reference these types as part of their execution.
Might: The combat statistic of a Unit. Used to determine a Unit's contribution to Combat, as well as when it is Killed by damaging effects.
If a Unit ever has nonzero damage marked on it equalling or exceeding its Might, it is Killed.
If a unit's Might is ever less than 0, it is treated as 0 for all purposes.
Units can have damage marked on them.
When spells, abilities, or other game effects deal damage, Units mark that damage on them temporarily. This can be tracked with coins, dice, or other markers, or by memory.
Damage is Healed from Units at two specific times:
At the end of each player's turn.
During a Combat Cleanup.
See rule 444.1. for more information about Combat Cleanups.
Units enter the Board exhausted.
This can be altered by Accelerate or similar game effects.
See rule 731. Accelerate for more information.
Units have the Inherent Ability to perform a Standard Move.
This action is limited in when it can be performed.
This action can be done any time during a player's Action Phase.
This action cannot be performed during a Closed State.
This action cannot be performed during a Showdown.
Exhausting the Unit is the Cost for this action.
Players may perform multiple Units' standard move simultaneously.
When a Move like this is declared by a player, the units' Destination must be the same.
When a Move like this is declared by a player, the Origins do not need to be the same.
The Costs of Exhausting the Units are also paid Simultaneously.
The Destinations where Units can Move to with their Standard Move are restricted:
Units may move from their Base to a Battlefield.
Units cannot Move to a Battlefield that already has units from 2 other players present.
Units may move from a Battlefield to their Base.
Ganking is a unique ability that affects a Unit's Standard Move
Units with Ganking may use their Standard Move to Move from Battlefield to Battlefield.
See rule 736. Ganking for more information.
Units may have Activated Abilities.
Activated Abilities are Game Effects that are written as Costs followed by a ":", and then succeeded by an effect.
See rule 369. Activated Abilities for more information.
The Activated Ability of Units may be executed at any time during the controlling player's Action Phase during an Open State, and not during a Showdown.
This follows the same process as playing a card.
See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
This behaves, once activated, like a spell without an associated card.
Gear
Gear are:
A Game Object
While on the Board.
Gear can only be played to a player's Base.
Gear and their details are Public Information while on the Board.
Gear can be chosen, affected, or manipulated by spells, effects, or game actions that specify Gear.
Gear can be Killed.
See rule 415. Kill for more information.
While in the Trash
Gear are treated as Cards before Game Objects, similar to the Hand.
They retain the properties of being Gear, but are not on the Board and thus cannot take actions or be affected by spells, abilities, or game actions that affect Gear on the Board.
Gear can be affected by spells and game effects that affect Gear in the Trash.
A Card Type
This is a unique identifier that some spells or abilities will use to restrict what they can choose or affect.
The card type is relevant in all zones.
Gear have several Intrinsic Properties unique to them.
Gear enters play Ready.
Gear can only be played to a player's Base.
If a Gear is at a Battlefield for any reason, then it is immediately recalled to its controller's Base as a corrective action.
See rule 432. Recalls for more information.
Gear may have Activated Abilities.
Activated Abilities are Game Effects that are written as Costs followed by a ":", and then succeeded by an effect.
See rule 369. Activated Abilities for more information.
The Activated Ability of Gear may be executed at any time during the controlling player's Action Phase during an Open State, and not during a Showdown.
This follows the same process as playing a card.
See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
This behaves, once activated, like a spell without an associated card.
Spells
Spell is a card type.
A spell can be played during an Open State Outside of Showdowns on its controller's turn.
A spell is controlled by the player who played it.
A spell creates a game effect according to its instructions and is then placed in the Trash of the player who owns it.
When a spell is successfully played, a player executes the rules text of the spell. This is called Resolving the spell.
Spells have their rules text executed from top to bottom when they are Resolved.

If a later part of a spell applies a Replacement Effect that alters earlier parts of the spell, apply those replacement effects as appropriate. Example: A spell says "Choose a unit. Kill it the next time it takes damage this turn." and "[Legion] — Kill it now instead. (Get the effect if you've played another card this turn.)" If the Legion condition is satisfied, the unit is killed immediately and the instruction to kill it the next time it takes damage is ignored, even if the unit remains on the board somehow.

While a spell or ability on the chain is Resolving, no other spells or abilities can be finalized on the chain or resolved, including triggered abilities or game effects that would occur as a result of the execution of the spell.
Finish resolving all effects of a spell before addressing anything the spell may have triggered or caused through execution.
Certain Keywords on spells are not executable rules text, but instead intrinsic properties of the spell.
These determine inherent properties and behaviors of the spell before being played or while on the chain.
These keywords are:
Action
This indicates that, in addition to being able to be played during an Open State, this spell may also be played during Open States during Showdowns.
Reaction
Grants all cases and rules of Action.
In addition to all prior cases, may also be played during all forms of Closed State.
This will result in this spell resolving before spells and abilities that are already on the chain.
Runes
Rune is a Card Type.
A Rune is not a Main Deck card.
This means, despite remaining on the Board until Recycled or otherwise removed from the board, it is not a Permanent.
Runes are kept in the Rune Deck.
Exactly 12 Rune cards chosen during Deck Construction.
See rule 103.3. Rune Deck for more information.
When a Rune is Recycled it is returned to the Rune Deck, not the Main Deck.
See rule 403. Recycle for more information.
Runes produce the resources needed to pay costs.
Runes produce Energy and Power.
Energy is used to pay numeric Energy costs.
Energy has no Domain.
Energy has no type.
Power is used to pay Domain-associated Power Costs.
Power has a Domain.
Power's Domain usually corresponds to the Domain of the Rune that produced it.
Some Power is Universal and can be used to pay for costs of any Domain.
Basic Runes
There are six Basic Runes, each with a Domain corresponding to its name:
Fury Rune
Calm Rune
Mind Rune
Body Rune
Chaos Rune
Order Rune
A Basic Rune always has the following two Abilities:
[E]: [Reaction] — Add [1].
Recycle this: [Reaction] — Add [C].
The Power added this way corresponds to the Domain of the Rune that is being Recycled.
Rune Pools
The Rune Pool is a conceptual collection of a player's available Energy and Power available to pay Costs.
When a card adds Energy or Power, it is added to the controlling player's Rune Pool.
Players must first add Energy and Power to their Rune Pool in order to be able to spend it to play cards or pay for Abilities with costs.
Energy and Power do not have a physical marker or tracker, although players may wish to use a physical tracker if they are retaining unspent Energy and Power over the course of their turn.
Every player's Rune Pool empties at the end of each player's draw phase and the end of each player's turn.
Any unspent Energy or Power are lost.
All Abilities that include the action "Add" are abilities that are adding Energy or Power to the Rune Pool.
See rule 416. Add for more information.
Battlefields
Battlefields are Game Objects.
Battlefields are Owned by a player.
Battlefields are not shuffled into Decks at the start of a game.
Battlefields are not played during the course of regular play.
Battlefields are established at the start of a game and remain in place for the duration of regular play.
Battlefields cannot be Killed during the course of regular play.
Battlefields cannot be Moved.
Battlefields are Locations.
Battlefields can be Origins of moves.
Battlefields can be Destinations of moves.
Any number of Units can be present at a Battlefield.
Battlefields can be targeted by spells or game effects.
Battlefields can have Passive Abilities.
See rule 360. Passive Abilities for more information.
Battlefields can have Triggered Abilities.
See rule 375. Triggered Abilities for more information.
Battlefields are not Permanents.
The number of Battlefields on the Board is determined by the Mode of Play.
Legends
Legends are Game Objects.
Legends are Owned by a player.
Legends are not shuffled into Decks at the start of a game.
Legends are not played during the course of regular play.
Legends are established at the start of a game, and remain in place for the duration of regular play.
Legends cannot be Killed during the course of regular play.
Legends cannot be Moved.
Legends can be targeted by spells or game effects.
Legends can have Passive Abilities.
See rule 360. Passive Abilities for more information.
Legends can have Triggered Abilities.
See rule 375. Triggered Abilities for more information.
Legends can have Activated Abilities.
See rule 369. Activated Abilities for more information.
Legends are not Permanents.
Legends may have one or more Domains.
The Legend determines the Domain Identity of cards its owner can include.
See rule 101. Deck Construction for more information.
Tokens
Tokens are Game Objects created by spells and abilities during play.
Tokens can be represented by anything. Printed tokens are included in Riftbound booster packs, but they are not required to play a token.

A token's controller is the controller of the spell or ability that created it, unless the token's type innately determines control or that spell or ability specifies that a different player is the token's controller.
A token's owner is the player who controlled the effect that created it.
The effect that creates a token may specify the conditions or circumstances under which it enters the board. These stipulations may alter the usual steps for playing a card.
The effect may state that the token enters ready or exhausted, if that state is contrary to the default for the token's type.
The effect may restrict the location to which the token may be played.
The effect may grant temporary abilities or modifications to the token.
Tokens are not cards.
Tokens have some properties in common with cards.
Tokens are played by their owner if their card type is played, following all the applicable steps for playing a card plus any restrictions or modifications from the effect that created the token.
See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
Token units have a Might.
Tokens may have one or more tags.

Tokens have a type. They follow all rules for their type unless otherwise specified. Example: A token unit is a unit. It enters exhausted, can take the standard move action, deals damage equal to its Might in combat, is destroyed if it takes damage equal to or greater than its might, can be chosen or otherwise affected by spells or abilities that choose or affect units, etc.
Tokens differ from cards in some ways.
Tokens do not have costs.
Tokens do not have domains.
Tokens are created on the board and cannot exist elsewhere.
If a token is put into any Non-Board Zone, it ceases to exist immediately after moving to its new zone.
The spell or ability that creates a token specifies some of its characteristics. It may have other characteristics, as listed below.
A 1[M] Recruit token is a domainless unit token with 1 Might and the Recruit tag.
A 3[M] Sprite token with Temporary is a domainless unit token with 3 Might, the Fae tag, and the Temporary keyword.
See rule 742. Temporary for more information.
Control
Control is the concept of a player having influence of a Game Object and applies differently to different card types.
Battlefields
Control is established over Battlefields through the course of play.
Control is a binary state for Battlefields and an Identifier for players.
A Battlefield is Controlled or Uncontrolled.
A Battlefield is Controlled by a specific player or Controlled by no one.
Control can be Contested through the course of play.
Contested is a temporary status applied to the battlefield when a Unit controlled by a Player who does not currently Control that Battlefield Moves or otherwise becomes present there.
Units moving to or being played to a battlefield apply Contested status if that battlefield is not already contested and that Unit’s controller does not already control that battlefield.
A Battlefield remains Contested until Control is established or re-established.
While a Battlefield remains Contested, Control of a Battlefield cannot change.
The state of a Battlefield being Contested is used to determine when Combat should occur, when a Showdown without a Combat should occur, and when Control will change.
At this time Game Effects cannot reference this status.
Control is established by having Units at a Battlefield at the end of a Showdown or Combat after applying the contested status.
If a player controls Units at a Battlefield, outside of Combat, they maintain Control of that Battlefield for as long as they have Units at that Battlefield.
A player maintains control of a Battlefield while it is being Contested by an opponent.
If a player has no Units at a Battlefield, they lose Control of that Battlefield immediately, unless it is Contested.
Control is a constant state.
Control of a Battlefield determines Control of its Abilities.

While a Battlefield is Controlled, its Controller controls its Abilities. That player takes responsibility for adding them to the Chain if applicable, and makes all choices required by them unless otherwise specified.

While a Battlefield is Uncontrolled, its Abilities are also Uncontrolled. The Turn Player takes responsibility for adding them to the Chain if applicable, makes all choices required by them unless otherwise specified, and is treated as their Controller if any game rule or effect requires one. Example: The Arena’s Greatest is a battlefield that reads “At the start of each player's first Beginning Phase, that player gains 1 point.” This ability will usually trigger while the battlefield has no controller. If it does, the Turn Player goes through the steps of adding the ability to the chain and receives priority after doing so, exactly as if they controlled the ability.

“You” in a battlefield’s abilities refers to the battlefield’s Controller, as does the implied “you” in instructions like “draw 1.” If the battlefield has no Controller, “you” refers to no one, and all such instructions are ignored.
Everything Else
When a player Plays a Card or other Game Object, they are established as that Game Object's Controller.
For Spells, they are the Spell's Controller.
That player chooses targets.
That player chooses modes.
That player pays costs.
For Permanents and Runes, when they Enter the Board, that player is assigned as that Game Object's Controller.
That player may make decisions about the Game Object's Inherent Abilities.
That player may make decisions about the Game Object's Unique Abilities.
That player may make decisions about any game effects or decisions necessary while the card is being played.
That player may make decisions about any game effects created from "When you play me" effects of Permanents.
For Abilities, they are the Ability’s Controller.
By default, the Controller of an Ability’s Source is the Controller of that Ability.
Changes to Control of an Ability’s Source do not change Control of that Ability.
That player chooses targets.
That player chooses modes.
That player pays costs.
When a game effect or rules text refers to the Controller of a specific object, it can be referring to either context interchangeably.
The method of assignment of control is different, but the status of Control is the same across all Game Objects.
Playing the Game
The Turn
Play continues cyclically until one player wins.
The phases of a turn are rigid, but the actions taken during those steps can be done in any order, unless otherwise specified.
Game Actions of any nature are performed one at a time and are executed completely.
Game Actions cannot be performed simultaneously for any reason.
If one or more actions, game effects, or Triggered Abilities are activated simultaneously, then Turn Order is referenced to organize the sequence of actions.
See rule 375. Triggered Abilities for more information.
The Turn Player is the player taking the current turn.

When there are no items on the Chain and the Turn Player cannot or chooses not to perform any Discretionary Actions, the current phase or step of the turn ends and the next phase, step, or turn begins.
The Turn Player changes when the current Turn Player reaches the End of all of the Phases of their Turn.
States of the Turn
At any given time, the turn is in either a Neutral State or a Showdown State.
If a Showdown is in progress, the turn is in a Showdown State.
Only cards and abilities with the Action or Reaction keywords can be played or activated in a Showdown State.
If no Showdown is in progress, the turn is in a Neutral State.
At any given time, the turn is in either an Open State or a Closed State.
If a Chain exists, the turn is in a Closed State.
Only cards and abilities with the Reaction keyword can be played or activated in a Closed State.
If no Chain exists, the turn is in an Open State.
These descriptions can be combined, such that the turn is always in one of these four states:
Neutral Open: There is no Showdown in progress and no Chain exists.
By default, cards can be played and abilities activated only when a player has priority on their turn in a Neutral Open state.
Neutral Closed: There is no Showdown in progress and a Chain exists.
Showdown Open: A Showdown is in progress and no Chain exists.
Showdown Closed: A Showdown is in progress and a Chain exists.
Priority and Focus
At any given time, up to one player has Priority.
Priority is the singular exclusive right to take Discretionary Actions.
See rule 398.1. Discretionary Actions for more information.
The player with Priority can take appropriately timed Discretionary Actions.
If no player has Priority, no player can take Discretionary Actions.
Players can always take and make choices for Limited Actions when instructed, regardless of Priority.
A player receives Priority at the following times:
When the turn is in a Neutral Open State during their Action Phase.
When the turn is in a Showdown State and they gain Focus.
When the turn is in a Closed State and they control the next item on the Chain.
When the turn is in a Closed State, they are the next Player in Turn Order, and the player with Priority passes.
When a player is granted Priority, it is either created if no player has it or taken from the player with Priority.
At any given time, up to one player has Focus.
Focus is the permission to take appropriately timed Discretionary Actions when the turn is in a Showdown Open State.
See rule 307. States of the Turn for more information.
The player with Focus must obey any additional restrictions on which Discretionary Actions may be performed.
Example: A player with Focus may not play spells or activate abilities that don't have the Action or Reaction keywords.
A player who gains Focus also gains Priority.
A player who passes Priority retains Focus.
A player may not make discretionary actions with Focus unless they also possess Priority.
If the turn is in a Neutral State, no player has Focus.
Phases of the Turn
Start of Turn
Awaken Phase
The Turn Player readies all Game Objects they control that are able to be readied.
See rule 402. Ready for more information.
Beginning Phase
Beginning Step
At the start of Beginning Phase game effects take place.
Scoring Step
Holding occurs at this time.
See rule 445. Scoring for more information.
Reminder: In Modes of Play with Teams, Battlefields held by a Teammate of the Turn Player during this phase are disqualified from being scored this turn by the Turn Player.
Specific game effects or abilities will reference this timing and phase as necessary.
Channel Phase
The Turn Player gains their additional runes for the turn.
The Turn Player channels 2 runes from their Rune Deck.
See rule 417. Channel for more information.
If there are fewer than 2 runes in the Rune Deck, they channel as many as possible.
Perform any actions as instructed by game objects during this time.
Draw Phase
The Turn Player gains their additional card for the turn.
The Turn Player draws 1.
If there are no cards remaining in their Main Deck to draw, the Turn Player has been Burned Out.
See rule 418. Burn Out for more information.
After completing the Burn Out the Turn Player still Draws 1.
Perform any actions as instructed by game objects during this time.
As the Draw Phase ends, each player's Rune Pool empties.
See rule 161. Rune Pools for more information.
Action Phase
When all steps of the Start of Turn have been completed, the Action Phase begins.
The Action Phase has no defined structure.
A player may take any number of Discretionary Actions they are able to perform during this phase.
See rule 398.1. Discretionary Actions for more information.
This is denoted as a Neutral Open State, and only the Turn Player has the ability to play spells or activate abilities.
See rule 307. States of the Turn for more information.
In Modes of Play with teammates, the Turn Player's teammates may play spells and activate abilities, including ones without Action or Reaction.
In Modes of Play with Teammates, spells may be played by Teammates of the Turn Player during this time, but the actions of the Turn Player take precedence.
As a result of a player taking Discretionary Actions, one or more structured phases may occur.
Combat
A Combat phase occurs as a result of Units controlled by opposing players being present at the same Battlefield.
This could be the result of a Standard Move Standard Action, a Spell, or other Game Effect.
The source effect does not change the structure or flow of Combat once initiated.
A Combat can only occur between two players.
See rule 437. Combat for more information.
Play proceeds following the steps of combat.
See rule 441. Steps of Combat for more information.
Combat will also include a Showdown.
Showdowns
A Showdown occurs when a Combat occurs.
Showdowns that occur as a result of Combat are a Sub-Phase of Combat.
A Showdown is marked as Staged at a Battlefield when the Contested status is applied to a Battlefield with no current controller.
Showdowns that occur as a result of a player moving to an empty Battlefield are a stand-alone Phase and do not create a Combat.
A Showdown is a structured Window of Opportunity where Players may play cards and activate abilities with Action or Reaction.
See rule 337. Showdowns for more information.
When a player has no more Discretionary Actions they wish to execute, they must indicate they are ending their turn.
This ends the Action Phase.
Play proceeds to the End of Turn.
End of Turn Phase
Ending Step
At the end of the turn Game Effects take place.
Specific game effects and abilities will reference this timing and phase as necessary.
End of Turn Cleanup
Invoke an End of Turn Special Cleanup.
See rule 318. Cleanups for more information.
Insert “2c. Heal all Units.”
Expiration Step
All "this turn" effects expire simultaneously.
As the Expiration Step ends, all players' Rune Pools empty. Any unspent Energy and Power are lost.
The Turn Player then becomes the next player in Turn Order.
Cleanups
A Cleanup occurs at the following times:
After the game transitions to or from an Open or Closed state
After the game transitions between Phases
After a Pending Item becomes a Legal Item on the Chain
After a Chain Item is removed from the Chain for any reason
After any number of Game Objects enter or leave the Board
After the status of any number of Game Objects changes for any reason
After a Move is completed
While a Cleanup is occurring, Chain Items cannot be Resolved.
New Pending Items can be added, but Legal Items cannot be executed and Priority and Focus are not passed or awarded.

If an event occurs during a Cleanup that qualifies for a Cleanup, another Cleanup will occur immediately after the first completes, repeating until a Cleanup occurs with no new change in the game’s state.
When a Cleanup occurs, the following steps occur in order:
1. If a player has as many points as the Victory Score, that player wins.
2. Handle outstanding board state

2a. All Units that have non-zero Damage marked on them equalling or exceeding their Might that have Deathknell abilities will trigger their Deathknell ability now, making note of their current location, attributes, and other information relevant to add the trigger as a Pending Item
See rule 734 Deathknell for more information.
2b. All Units that have non-zero Damage marked on them equalling or exceeding their Might are killed and placed in their owners' Trash.
3. Assign or Remove the Attacker or Defender designation from Units as needed if there is a Combat in progress
If there are Units present at the Battlefield the Combat is taking place at, but do not have a designation, they gain the same designation as their Controller now

If there are Units present at the Battlefield the Combat is taking place at, but have the opposite designation of their controller, they lose that designation, and gain the same designation as their controller now
If there are Units at locations other than the Battlefield that the Combat is taking place at, but have either Attacker or Defender designations, they lose those designations now
4. Battlefields with no Units occupying them and no Contested status become Uncontrolled.
5. Recall all Gear at Battlefields. Remove all Hidden cards from all Battlefields that are not controlled by the same player and place them in their owner's Trash.
6. Mark a Showdown as Staged at each Battlefield that Contested was applied to that is Uncontrolled.
The Showdown remains Staged at each Battlefield that is Contested and has only units present controlled by the player that applied Contested
6a. If Units of an opposing player are present at a Battlefield that has a Showdown staged before it can be Opened, the Showdown will cease being Staged
7. Mark a Combat as Staged at each Battlefield that Contested was applied to that have Units present controlled by opposing players.
The Combat remains Staged at that Battlefield as long as there are Units present from two opposing players there.
7a. If Units of two opposing players are no longer present at a Battlefield that has a Combat Staged before it has opened, the Combat will cease being Staged
8. Finalize any Pending Items on the Chain
9. If the current state is a Neutral Open State and one or more Showdowns are Staged, the Turn Player chooses one of those Battlefields. A Showdown begins there.
10. If the current state is a Neutral Open State and Combat is Staged at one or more Battlefields, the Turn Player chooses one of those Battlefields. Combat begins there.
Special Cleanups are Cleanup steps invoked at specific times that have additional steps not present in a normal Cleanup.
When a Special Cleanup is invoked, the unique steps added will be inserted and defined by the sub-section that invokes it.
Example: When a Combat Cleanup is invoked, the Combat section defines what steps are added to the Cleanup.
If events during a Special Cleanup require another Cleanup, a normal Cleanup is invoked, not another iteration of the Special Cleanup.
Chains and Showdowns
Players can act during the following Windows of Opportunity that occur during the course of regular play:
During a Chain
During a Showdown
Chains
The Chain is a Non-Board Zone that temporarily exists whenever a card is played or an ability is activated.
Cards are placed here as part of the process of being played.
Abilities are queued here as part of the process of resolving.
See rule 357. Abilities for more information.
Cards and abilities added to the chain are added as Pending Chain Items that become Finalized Chain Items.
Pending Items are on the Chain.
Chain Items are Pending until the “Check Legality” step of playing a card.
See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
When a Pending Chain Item is no longer Pending it is finalized and becomes a Finalized Chain Item.
The Chain exists as long as a Chain Item is on it.
Only one Chain can exist at a time.
If a card would begin to be played while a Chain already exists, it is placed on the existing Chain.
The State of the Turn is partially determined by whether or not the Chain currently exists.
The turn is said to be in a Closed State if a Chain exists.
Cards of all Categories, by default, cannot be played during a Closed State.
Card abilities, by default, cannot be played during a Closed State.
The turn is said to be in an Open State if no Chain exists.
Steps of Resolving Chain Items
Whenever a card or token is played or an ability is activated or triggered, a Chain is created.
The player that created the chain becomes the first Active Player.
The Active Player is a designator similar to, but distinct from, Turn Player.
Similar to the Turn Player, this designation will pass between players over the course of play.
Step 1: Finalize
If one or more Items are Pending, their controllers must complete the steps of Playing those Pending Items until they are Finalized Items or leave the Chain.
This process does not pass Priority.
Each Item is Finalized in the order it was appended to the Chain.
Abilities that Add resources, Units, and Gear resolve immediately when Finalized and do not progress to Step 2: Execute.
See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
If the Chain is empty, play proceeds in an Open State.
If the Chain is not empty and there are one or more Pending Items, repeat Step 1.
If the Chain is not empty and there are no Pending Items, the controller of the newest item on the chain gains Priority and becomes the Active Player. Proceed to Step 2: Execute.
Step 2: Execute
The Active Player may do any the following:
Play a Card that is legally timed.
Cards, by default, cannot be played during a Closed State.
A Legally Timed Card would be a Card with Reaction.
Other exceptions may be created during regular play.
The card will be added to the chain as a Pending Item, following the steps of playing a card.
This can be an additional card to the item that Started the Chain in the case of the first Active Player after creating the Chain.
Whether a Card is legally timed is evaluated during the “Check Legality” step of Playing a Card.
See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information.
Playing a card will create one or more Pending Items. Return to Step 1: Finalize.
Activate Abilities of Game Objects that are legally timed.
See rule 386. Playing or Activating Abilities for more information.
All rules for legally timed cards apply to legally timed abilities.
Activating abilities will create one or more Pending Items. Return to Step 1: Finalize.
Pass Priority
The Active Player passes Priority to the next Player in Turn Order. Proceed to Step 3: Pass.
Step 3: Pass
If all players have passed Priority without adding any items to the Chain, proceed to Step 4: Resolve.
Otherwise, the Active Player passes Priority to the next Player in Turn Order. Return to Step 3: Execute.
Step 4: Resolve
The newest item on the Chain resolves. Execute its game effects in their entirety.
See rule 346. Playing Cards for more information on resolving spells.
See rule 386. Playing or Activating Abilities for more information on resolving abilities.
If the Chain is empty, play proceeds in an Open State.
If the Chain is not empty and there are one or more Pending Items, return to Step 1: Finalize.
If the Chain is not empty and there are no Pending Items, the controller of the newest item on the chain gains Priority and becomes the Active Player. Return to Step 2: Execute.
Showdowns
A Showdown is a Window of Opportunity in which Players have an Open State in which they may play Spells in an alternating fashion.
Each spell played this way creates a Chain as normal.
The State of the turn is partially determined by whether or not a Showdown is in progress.
The turn is said to be in a Showdown State if a Showdown is in progress.
Cards of all Categories, by default, cannot be played during a Showdown State.
Card abilities, by default, cannot be played during a Showdown State.
The turn is said to be in a Neutral State if no Showdown is in progress.
A Showdown begins when Control of a Battlefield is Contested and the turn is in a Neutral Open State.
If Control of a Battlefield is Contested between two players, then a Showdown will be opened as the first step of Combat.
See rule 437. Combat for more information.

If Control of a Battlefield is Contested and the Battlefield in question is uncontrolled when it becomes Contested, a Showdown is opened during the Cleanup at the end of the action that caused the Battlefield to become Contested.
As a Showdown begins, the player who applied Contested status to the Battlefield gains Focus.
When a Showdown begins, it may or may not begin with an Initial Chain.
Showdowns that open as a result of Combat may have an Initial Chain of Triggered Abilities.

These Triggered Abilities should be put on the chain first by the player with Focus, then proceeding with players without the Defender designation in Turn Order. Finally, the player with the Defender designation will add their Triggered Abilities, if any, to the Chain.
If there are no such Triggered Abilities present during a Combat-initiated Showdown then no Initial Chain is created, but the Showdown will still proceed.
When the last item on the chain resolves during a Showdown, Focus passes, and the next Player gains both Focus and Priority.
Focus does not pass when the last item on the Initial Chain resolves, if there was one. Instead the player with Focus proceeds with play.
During a Showdown, the player with Focus may do one of the following:
Play a spell that is legally timed.
The spell will start a Chain as normal.
Activate Abilities of Game Objects that are legally timed.
See rule 357. Abilities for more information.
Pass.
If all Players have passed once in sequence, the Showdown ends.
Perform a Cleanup.
Otherwise, Focus passes to the next Player in Turn Order.
If all players pass Focus without playing a spell or activating an ability, then the Showdown Closes.
If this Showdown opened as a result of Combat, proceed with the remaining steps of Combat to resolve the phase.
See rule 441. The Steps of Combat for more information.
If this Showdown opened as a result of Contested being applied to a Battlefield without a controller, do one of the following:
If only one player’s Units remain at the Battlefield, and if that player does not already Control the Battlefield, that player establishes Control over the Battlefield.
See rule 179. Control for more information on Control.
See rule 446.1. for more information on Conquering.
This results in a Conquer if that player has not yet scored that Battlefield this turn.
If two players’ Units remain at the Battlefield, Control cannot be established and the Battlefield remains Contested. This results in a Staged Combat.
See rule 437. Combat for more information.
The player who applied Contested to the Battlefield will be the Attacker in the subsequent Combat.
Playing Cards
Playing a card is the act of a player utilizing their cards.
A card is Played when it has finished this process in its entirety.
Tokens are not cards, but can still be Played.
See rule 173. Tokens for more information.
Cards have different behaviors when played.
Permanents become Game Objects when Played.
Spells create game effects that are executed, then the card is placed in the trash when Played.
Cards have different states during the process of being played.
When initially being played cards are Pending, as Pending Chain Items.
Near the end of the process cards will cease being Pending and become Finalized Chain Items.
The Process of Play
1. Remove the card from the zone you are playing it from and put it onto the Chain.
This Closes the State.
See rule 307. States of the Turn for more information.
This item becomes Pending.
If another Card Effect or ability is currently resolving, continue resolving it before proceeding with any further steps of this process.
2. Make necessary choices.
If the card is a spell, or has an effect that specifies a choice "As I am played," those choices are made now.
For Units, choose a valid Location where that Unit will be placed upon being Played.
By default, Valid locations include the controller’s Base or a Battlefield the controller controls.
Some Game Effects may grant players permission to play Units to locations that are not normally Valid. Such locations become Valid for the purposes of Playing the Unit..
For Spells and Abilities that Move one or more Units, choose a valid Location as the Move Destination for each Move that will be performed.
If a card requires you to specifically choose one or more Game Objects, that choice is made now.
This does not include cards that affect one or more Game Objects based on criteria.
Example: "Stun a unit at a battlefield" is a Choice.
Example: "Kill all gear" is not a Choice.
This does not include making choices for Triggered Abilities of permanents, even if those abilities trigger when the permanent is played.
Example: A unit with a triggered ability that says "When I'm played, kill a unit" does not require you to choose a target as it's played. The target will be chosen when the ability triggers.
See rule 375. Triggered Abilities for more information.
Targeting
When a card Chooses one or more specific Game Objects to affect, it is Targeted.
In order to put a spell or ability on the chain, valid choices must be made for all targets.
A target is a valid choice if it meets all of the following requirements:
It is a permanent or rune on the board, a spell or ability on the chain, a player or zone, or specified explicitly or implicitly as being in some other zone.
e.g., “Kill a unit” targets a unit on the board.
e.g., “Recycle a unit from your trash” targets a unit card in your trash.
“Unit,” “gear,” and “rune” refer to objects on the Board unless specified otherwise.
“Spell” and “ability” refer to objects on the Chain unless specified otherwise.
“Facedown card” refers to a card in a Facedown Zone unless specified otherwise.
“Legend” refers to a legend in the Legend Zone.
“Chosen Champion” and “unit in the Champion Zone” refer to a unit in the Champion Zone unless specified otherwise.
It meets all targeting restrictions.
e.g., A unit is a valid target for a spell that refers to a “unit at a battlefield,” “enemy unit,” “unit you control,” or “unit with Might 4 or greater” only if it meets the appropriate criteria.
It is not the spell or ability itself.
e.g., A spell that says “Counter a spell” cannot target itself.
e.g., An ability of a permanent can target that permanent, because abilities and their sources are separate objects.
If a spell or ability requires one or more players to choose objects, players, or zones that are not targets, those choices are made on resolution.
Passive abilities never have targets.
Replacement effects never have targets.
Units and gear never have targets, although their abilities may.
A game object, player, or zone mentioned in the text of a spell, activated ability, or triggered ability is a target UNLESS any of the following are true:
It is in a zone whose information status is not Public.
e.g., “Ready a legend” targets a legend, because the Legend Zone is Public.
e.g., “Return a unit from your trash to your hand” targets a unit card in your trash, because your trash is Public.
e.g., “You may play a unit from your hand, ignoring its costs” does not target a unit card in your hand, because your hand is not a public zone.
Public zones are Battlefield Zones, Bases, Trashes, Legend Zones, Champion Zones, and Facedown Zones.
It is included only as part of a targeting restriction for another choice.
e.g., “Kill a unit at a battlefield” targets a unit, but not a battlefield, because the units are targets and “at a battlefield” is a restriction.
e.g., “Kill all units at a battlefield” targets a battlefield, but not any units.
e.g., “Move a unit to a battlefield” targets both a unit and a battlefield.
It is included only as part of a cost, trigger condition, or replacement effect.
e.g., “As an additional cost to play me, kill a friendly unit” doesn’t target anything.
e.g., “When a friendly unit dies, kill a gear” targets a gear, but not a friendly unit.
e.g., “When you play me, the next time a friendly unit would die this turn, return it to your hand instead” doesn’t target anything. The replacement effect applies when any friendly unit dies.
e.g., “Choose a friendly unit. The next time it would die this turn, return it to your hand instead” targets a friendly unit, because “choose a friendly unit” is not part of the replacement effect.
This includes costs within instructions, identified by phrases like “[do X] to [do Y].” The cost within that instruction is “[do X].”
e.g., “When I hold, you may kill another friendly unit here to draw 1” does not target anything.
e.g., “When you play me, you may spend a buff to move a friendly unit” targets the friendly unit, but not the buff.
It is programmatically selected based on its characteristics rather than chosen by the spell or ability’s controller.
e.g., “Kill all units at a battlefield” targets a battlefield, but does not target any units.
e.g., “Kill all units at battlefields” doesn’t target anything.
e.g., “Destroy a unit. Its controller draws 2 cards” targets the unit, but not its controller.
e.g., “Ready your legend” doesn’t target anything, because you can only have one legend.
e.g., “Ready a friendly legend” targets a legend, because in a 2v2 game there are two friendly legends.
e.g., “Recycle all cards in your trash” doesn’t target anything, because it affects all cards and you only have one trash.
This exception applies solely to objects for which no choice is ever possible.
This exception does not apply to objects that are the only valid choice at the moment a spell or ability is placed on the chain, but which would require a choice under other circumstances.
e.g., “Kill a unit at a battlefield” always targets a unit, even if that unit is the only unit currently at a battlefield.
It is part of a set of objects chosen in whole or in part by other players.
e.g., “Each player kills a unit they control” does not target. Each player, including the one who played the spell, chooses a unit to kill as the spell or ability resolves.
It is identified in an instruction that a player “must” complete.
e.g., “You must recycle one of your runes” doesn’t target anything. You choose from among your runes as the spell or ability resolves.
e.g., “Recycle a rune you control” targets a rune. You choose a rune you control as you put the spell or ability on the chain.
Some cards identify a group of Targets with Targeting Requirements that must be met by the group as a whole.
As they’re finalized on the chain, such cards can choose any group of valid targets that collectively fulfill the targeting restriction.

If the group of targets no longer collectively fulfill the targeting restriction as the spell or ability resolves, that spell or ability’s controller can choose a subset of the original targets that fulfills the targeting requirement for the spell or ability to affect.

Example: A player plays Fox-Fire, a spell that says in part “Kill any number of units at a battlefield with total Might 4 or less.” That player chooses four 1 [M] Recruit tokens at a single battlefield. As a Reaction, another player gives two of those Recruits +1 [M], so the Recruits’ Mights are 1, 1, 2, and 2. Then Fox-Fire resolves. The Recruits no longer have total Might 4 or less, so Fox-Fire’s controller must choose a legal subset of the original targets to affect. They could choose to kill the two 2 [M] Recruits, or the two 1 [M] Recruits plus one 2 [M] Recruit. The units they choose are Fox-Fire’s remaining legal targets. They can’t choose to affect units at the same battlefield that weren’t initially chosen as targets, and they can’t affect any units that are no longer at the chosen battlefield.
If a card specifies that a player may choose some number of Game Objects to be affected by a card, then all choices are considered targeted and chosen independently.

If a card specifies that a player chooses “any number” or “up to” some number of Game Objects to be affected, they may choose any number of available targets, including zero. If they choose zero, the spell or ability can be played without any targets.
Splitting
If a card specifies that an amount of damage may be split among some number of Units, then each Unit chosen is Targeted.
The Targets are chosen when the spell or ability is finalized on the chain.

A number of Targets can only be chosen up to, and not exceeding, the initial amount of damage available when the spell is played. Example: A player playing a spell that instructs them to "Split 5 damage" may only choose up to 5 units, but may choose fewer.
Each Target is valid, and contributes to Chosen triggers individually.
The choice of how much damage is divided across the split is not decided until the resolution of the spell or ability.
Each Target must receive a valid amount of damage.
Valid damage is a positive integer amount, greater than or equal to 1 damage.
If, at resolution of the spell or effect, there are more Targets than available damage to divide, then the player who controls the effect dealing damage determines which Targets cease being Targets.
Any costs that were paid, or effects that were triggered as a result of those Game Objects being chosen as Targets remain in effect, paid, or otherwise triggered.
These choices cannot be changed after this step.
A player may not make choices during this step that will deterministically result in illegal choices or actions later in this process unless they have no choice.

Example: A player plays Cruel Patron, which says "As an additional cost to play me, kill a friendly unit." They control exactly one unit, which is at a battlefield. They can't choose to play Cruel Patron to that battlefield, because by the time they have finished paying costs, they will no longer control that battlefield.
3. Determine Total Cost.
If an ability or instruction allows you to "ignore" one or more of a card's costs, set the appropriate Base Cost(s) of the card to zero.
If a card allows a player to play a card "ignoring its cost," its base Energy cost and base Power cost are set to zero.
If a card instructs a player to play a card "ignoring its Energy cost" or "ignoring its Power cost," only the appropriate cost is set to zero, and the remaining cost still applies.
Further additional costs and/or cost increases applied in subsequent steps may raise the card's Total Cost above zero.

Example: Legion Rearguard is a Fury unit that costs 2 Energy and 0 Power and has Accelerate. A player plays Legion Rearguard and is instructed to ignore its costs, but chooses to pay the Accelerate cost. They ignore Legion Rearguard's Base Cost of 2 Energy, but the optional additional cost of 1 Energy and 1 Fury Power is added to its Total Cost and must be paid.
Apply additional costs in any order.
Mandatory Additional Costs

Some Additional Costs specified by Passive Abilities on the card being played or another card are Mandatory, and must be paid to complete playing the card. They use the phrase "as an additional cost" and don't include the word "may."
Example: A unit has the passive ability "As an additional cost to play me, kill a friendly unit." To play that unit, a player must kill a friendly unit.
See rule 360. Passive Abilities for more information.
The cost imposed by the Deflect keyword is a Mandatory Additional Cost.
See rule 735. Deflect for more information.
Optional Additional Costs

Some Optional Costs specified by Passive Abilities on the card being played or another card are Non-Mandatory, and must be paid only if the player made the choice to pay them in rule 352. They use the phrase "as an additional cost" and the word "may."

Example: A unit has the ability "As you play me, you may discard 1 as an additional cost. If you do, reduce my cost by [2]." While playing the unit, its controller declares their intention to pay the additional cost in rule 352, applies that additional cost in rule 353.2, applies the discount granted by paying that cost in rule 353.4, and discards a card to pay that additional cost in rule 354.2.
See rule 360. Passive Abilities for more information.
Apply cost increases.
Apply discounts in any order.
Discounts may be applied by the card being played or by any other card or effect.
Discounts may say that cards "cost [amount] less" or that one or more of their costs are "reduced by [amount]."
If a discount applies a minimum cost, that minimum applies only to that discount.

Example: Eager Apprentice says "While I'm at a battlefield, the Energy costs for spells you play is reduced by [1], to a minimum of [1]." A player who controls Eager Apprentice and a unit with 7 Might plays Sky Splitter, a spell that costs 8 Energy and says "This spell's Energy cost is reduced by the highest Might among units you control." That player can choose to apply Eager Apprentice's discount first, reducing Sky Splitter's Energy cost to 7, then apply Sky Splitter's discount, reducing its Energy cost to 0. If they applied these discounts in the other order, Sky Splitter's Energy cost would be 1.
Discounts can reduce additional costs, including to 0.
An optional additional cost was "paid" if the player made the decision in rule 352 to pay it. It doesn't matter how much the player actually paid.

Example: Clockwork Keeper is a unit that costs 2 Energy and 0 Power and says "As you play me, you may pay [C] as an additional cost. If you do, draw " A player controls a card that says "Units you play cost [A] less." That player plays Clockwork Keeper and chooses to pay the optional additional cost of [C]. They will draw a card, even though the optional additional cost was reduced to 0.
Energy and Power costs can't be reduced below 0.

Costs may be Energy costs, Power costs, or non-standard costs. Example: A card reads "As an additional cost to play me, kill a friendly unit." Killing a friendly unit is an additional cost to play that card.
4. Pay the card's costs.
In total, pay the combined Energy cost (if any) and Power cost (if any).
During this step, the spell's controller can use activated abilities with the Reaction tag that Add resources to add Energy and Power to pay the spell's costs.
See rule 161. Rune Pools and rule 416. Add for more information.
In addition, pay any non-standard Cost summed in rule 353.2 in any order.
Costs that are replaced with other events by replacement effects are still considered paid.

Example: A player plays Cruel Patron, which says "As an additional cost to play me, kill a friendly unit." They also control Zhonya’s Hourglass, which says “If a friendly unit would die, kill this instead. Heal that unit, exhaust it, and recall it.” They choose to kill a friendly unit during rule 353.2, but as they pay the cost in rule 354.2, Zhonya’s Hourglass replaces that unit’s death. The cost is considered paid, and the player can continue playing Cruel Patron.
A player may not pay costs during this step that will deterministically result in illegal choices or actions later in this process unless they have no choice.

Example: A player plays Cruel Patron, which says "As an additional cost to play me, kill a friendly unit." They control multiple units, one of which is alone at a battlefield. During rule 352.2., they chose to play Cruel Patron to that battlefield. While paying costs, they can't choose to kill the unit at that battlefield, because then they will no longer control that battlefield and Cruel Patron cannot legally be played there. If they controlled that battlefield with multiple units, any of those units would be a legal choice, because they would still control the battlefield after killing one.
5. Check legality.
Check that all chosen targets are legal.
Ensure that the outcome of the effect of this card being played would not create an illegal state.
Example: Check that a spell's execution does not create a state where a Battlefield has Units controlled by 3 different players.
If the card, if continued to be played, would create an illegal state, or if a choice or action at this state is illegal, the actions taken in this process are undone and the action is cancelled.
6. Finalize this card and proceed with the card's category of Play.
This card is no longer Pending.
A Permanent leaves the Chain and becomes a Game Object.
Any passive abilities become active.
Execute all rules text on the card, from top to bottom.
If it is a Unit, it enters the Board exhausted at the Location that was chosen.
If it is a Gear, it enters the Board Ready at the player's Base.
A Spell lingers on the Chain.
This card becomes a Finalized Chain Item.
If there are other Pending Items on the Chain, then the controller of those Pending Items completes Steps 2 through 5 of Playing Cards for those items before continuing.
See rule 326. Chains for more information.
Other players have an opportunity to play Reactions before the resolution of spells.
See rule 326. Chains for more information.
Otherwise, execute the game effect of the spell, from top to bottom of the rules text of the card and then place the card in the Trash of the owning player.
Handling illegal and impossible instructions
The spell resolves even if some or all of its targets are illegal.
A target is illegal as the spell resolves if it no longer meets the targeting requirements of the spell, or if it has changed Zones to or from a Non-Board Zone.
If a target ceases to meet the targeting requirements while the spell is on the chain, then meets them again, it's a legal target.

Example: A spell targets "a unit at a battlefield." A player reacts with a spell that moves the unit to base, then another player reacts with a spell that moves it back to that battlefield, then the original spell resolves. The unit is a legal target.
If a target changes Zones to or from a Non-Board Zone and then returns to its original zone, it is no longer a legal target, because it's not treated as the same object.
Examples:
